channel.title: Do you work from home or you have a separate office?
channel.description:
Hello!
This question is for all of you who work alone, without employees: Do you work in your house, or do you have any rented office?

item.title: Do you work from home or you have a separate office?
item.dc:creator: AlanC
item.description:
A spare bedroom does me, however I find it is interruptions by phone and wattsapp that affect me more than anyone walking in.

That includes such as things as being expected to collect people from airports, take relatives to doctor visits etc etc, on the presumption that somehow working at home means I’m available for anything!

item.title: Do you work from home or you have a separate office?
item.dc:creator: cadbloke
item.description:
I just recently converted our laundry to a second home-office. I was sharing a desk with my wife but that just doesn’t work, you need to get out of the way and get in the zone. Also, sharing desk untidiness really doesn’t work. The ex-laundry is actually a good room, small but bright with 2 windows right in my eleyline and a west-facing view of the North Sydney CBD. It was totally wasted on a laundry. That’s downstairs in my ex-mancave. Yes, sacrifices.

It is also at the back corner of the house so I can hide in there when I need some space. I have 2x kids (4 & 1) so sometimes I need to listen out for them, other times I can shut myself away. I usually work in the evenings in there, I’m at client sites 4-5 days /week presently and the kids’ play room is right next to the office. Also, I like playing with my kids. My desk is an old school desk, complete with decades of graffiti carved into it. I sanded it back and oiled it. It’s more shabby than chic but so am I.

Kit-wise I have 2x identical 15" laptops with SSDs & 32GB (don’t skimp on this, it’s your main tool), a sweeet 27" monitor and 2x 24" monitors (one in portrait), all on a desk 1.5m wide. Adding monitors to a laptop with DisplayLink USB-DVI works very well. The room is 1.55m wide (x 3m long). It is a small space but works surprisingly well. I also bought a decent Ergohuman chair - this made an even bigger difference than I expected and was totally worth it.

I’ll post a pic when I remember.

Working from home, too — a separate lockable room in the house which is called “mom’s office.” I cherish my big monitor & don’t work from a laptop. I also really, really like morning traffic eliminated from my life

item.title: Do you work from home or you have a separate office?
item.dc:creator: Christopher
item.description:
For the first 5 years that Cogeian Systems was in business, I worked from home.

Then we had our second child. After 16 months of keeping her crib at the foot of our bed in the master bedroom, I thought “yeah, maybe it’s time to let this baby have a bedroom”. I moved into dedicated office space shortly thereafter.

It’s been interesting to see how my work habits have informed the way my kids see work and career.

At the time I moved into dedicated space, my son was 8 and his early perception of what “work” meant included Daddy being home all the time. He would sometimes just hang out in my home office as I worked, quietly drawing on the whiteboard, or coloring. Having me home all the time was normal, and he did a remarkably good job of respecting the fact that work time was work time. Hell, my wife was worse about violating my work boundaries than my 8-year-old-son was. When I moved out and got a real office, that was very exotic and exciting to him, and getting to visit “the office” was a big treat.

Fast forward to today, and now my daughter is 8 years old. Her perception of what “work” means is completely different than what my son’s was at that age. She’s never known a time when having Daddy work from home was normal; working from home is the exception, the begrudging last resort that happens only when there’s no other way. To my daughter, visiting me at “the office” is just-another-day type stuff; of course Dad is at the office, where else would he work? To her, the days when I work from home are exciting and exotic, a real event, just as the opposite was true for my son at her age.

I sometimes wonder how these two situations will impact my kids when it’s time for them to step into the world of work & career, if at all.

item.title: Do you work from home or you have a separate office?
item.dc:creator: Dmitry
item.description:
I used to work from home for many years, but this year I’m trying the new approach to work in a separate apartment, 15 minutes walking distance from home.

There are pros:

  • walking is good before long time sitting in the front of the PC
  • isolation: no one will come in. This is a problem when working at home - people feel free to ask something, and while it can be something minor, it distracts and slows down a lot.
  • better productivity overall. Things are done really faster there.

and cons:

  • have to go there, take food from home or order somethig, then go back - this takes up to an hour each day

item.title: Do you work from home or you have a separate office?
item.dc:creator: Clay_Nichols
item.description:
Home. Downstairs in the basement so I’m a bit isolated from the house. Also the stairs are a good “moat” around the office. Harder for people to wander in or me to wander out.

I save at least 30m a day in commute time vs. even having an office across the street. (There’s overhead in just leaving the house for work
But I’m pretty disciplined (or motivated I guess) for my work.

I know some people need the separation, which I can appreciate. Some folks even have a ritual of going outside and coming back in another door. Sort of analogous to an actor getting “in character” by putting on their characters clothes, shoes, hat, etc. It’s sort of a physical shift to cause a mental shift.

-Clay
